resources.string:
This course is an introduction to the Klingon language created by Dr. Marc Okrand for {Star Trek:src} and used in the films and TV series, most recently {Discovery:src}. It is assumed that you are in possession of {The Klingon Dictionary:src}, preferably the 1992 edition which includes an Addendum. In addition to most of the known vocabulary, this book also contains a largely complete description of the grammar. If you don\'t have it, go and purchase it now!

Other works by Dr. Okrand, such as {The Klingon Way:src} and {Klingon for the Galactic Traveler:src}, are also highly recommended. If you want to hear the sounds of spoken Klingon, the audiotapes {Conversational Klingon:src} and {Power Klingon:src} are essential. For more advanced students, additional clarifications on grammar and more vocabulary may be found in {HolQeD:src}, the journal of the Klingon Language Institute. The KLI also maintains a list of vocabulary revealed or expanded upon after the publication of {KGT:src}.

The {Star Trek:src} films which have a fair amount of spoken Klingon are {Star Trek III:src}, {Star Trek V:src}, and {Star Trek VI:src}. The series {Discovery:src} also has a large amount of spoken Klingon dialogue. (Dr. Okrand did not work on {Discovery:src}, but its dialogue was translated by expert speakers Robyn Stewart and Alan Anderson. Klingon subtitles for the show were written by Klingon teacher Lieven Litaer.)

One final word of warning: Do not rely on machine translation for Klingon. Software which can automatically translate between Klingon and another language does not exist. The only thing which can translate Klingon is a person who is competent in the language.

Click Continue when you are ready to begin.

The Klingon culture is a direct one, so let\'s get right down to business.

The most basic Klingon sentence consists of just the verb. Here are some Klingon verbs:
A verb by itself means that he/she/it is or they are performing the action described by that verb. For example, {Qong:sen} means he/she/it sleeps or they sleep.

As you may recall from the previous section, a verb by itself just means that he/she/it is or they are performing the action described by the verb. For example, {HIv:sen} means he/she/it attacks or they attack. To say that the Klingon attacks, put the word for Klingon after the verb, like this:

{HIv tlhIngan:sen} the Klingon attacks.

Klingon does not have articles (a, the), so this can also mean a Klingon attacks.

This means that the %2$s %3$s is performing the action described by %4$s %5$s.

Also, you answered %6$d out of %7$d review questions correctly in this section.

In the previous section, you learned that a verb by itself means he/she/it does something or they do something. To say I do something or you do something, you have to change the verb slightly.

In English, you change the ending of a verb to indicate who is doing something: I sleep, you sleep, but he/she/it sleeps. In Klingon, you change the beginning of the verb by adding a prefix. The prefix indicates both who or what is doing something (the subject), and if applicable, to whom or what the action is being done (the object).

Here are four prefixes which are used when there is no object.

For example, when combined with the verb {Qong:v} sleep, we get {jIQong:sen} I sleep, {bIQong:sen} you sleep, {maQong:sen} we sleep, and {SuQong:sen} you (plural) sleep.

Following the convention used in {TKD:src}, we will write the absence of a prefix as {0:v:suff} when we need to present it alongside non-empty prefixes. As you learned earlier, the absence of a prefix is used to indicate that the subject is he/she/it or they and the object is none.
